I think it would be good if you could use more than one trim for a piece of armor, for example, use one trim with diamond in a netherite chestplate, and then apply a completely different trim with any material (could be the same diamond, but it doesn't matter use another), and so, it will result in a very personalized armor of my choice, just like the banners works, but applying trims one over another. Also, it would be cool if the use of the material could bring something a bit useful for the armor, for example, emerald would lower villager prices by one (only the prices that are more than one), gold reduces range of piglin's agro to the player, and so on, making worth it to customize your armor, but not giving too much advantage/make obsolete other items.
Instead of using netherack in it’s crafting recipe it should use a harder to obtain block like guilded black stone which would also make sense since netherite is made partially out of gold.

I love the looks for the new armor trims, but I have to say that Netherite is already an interesting enough challenge to get full gear for in itself. The only reliable way to get it is to use TNT or beds, which is resource intensive if you don't have/use farms unless you're raiding villages for beds -which is mean- and so I don't think it should be made more challenging to make Netherite than it already is.

I mean, if each armor trim/upgrade etc would provide new functional uses rather than purely cosmetic, it would ultimately be worth it. But I think it should be left primarily the same, with the new templates needing to either be used only if you want the armor trims.

As of right now, I think armor trims are a cool cosmetic item, but way too expensive to replicate.

7 diamonds (or any diamond cost for that matter) is ultimately not worth duplicating something that simply does nothing more than allow you to design your armor.

It offers no in-game benefit, and is therefore too expensive and not really enticing enough to go after.

Netherite is expensive enough as it is, and rare to find even with the bed/tnt method of mining, and it is therefore needless to complicate that further.

I suggest that the trims each be given a functional use, even if it's relatively small, to begin to offset this.

To use the standard "armor template" I think Netherite armor should be given a smaller buff. Netherite is not above diamond to the same extent that diamond is to iron for example.

I believe the netherite upgrade template should be more expensive. It would be a great opportunity to make the netherite set more powerful and give it an actual advantage over diamond which is quite subtle at the moment. I think the netherite pickaxe should be able to instant mine deepslate and the axe should be able to instant mine some log kinds (both only with efficiency enchantments and possibly Haste of course). Especially the deepslate thing is important because there currently not being a tool that can do that greatly discourages people from building larger things in the lower layers of the world. The armour set should also get a more significant advantage over diamond.

For all of these things I would gladly use another netherite ingot for crafting the template - possibly even a netherite block.

What I specifically do not want to see is the crafting recipe getting removed in order to make the template harder to obtain. Especially on larger servers this unnecessarily inflates the world save size. Also exploring is exciting but not if you have to do it again and again when you lose your things.

So I've said this elsewhere, before I saw this thread but I'll say it here, too.
While I feel in Singleplayer worlds and on multiplayer servers that reset regularly this is a fine change, there is a massive barrier for those of us who run public servers which don't reset often, if at all.

Smithing Templates as aesthetic pieces are fine, but Netherite Upgrade Templates are often going to be extremely difficult to obtain as the nether is very well explored and widely looted on these servers.

A simple fix for these communities to this would see Netherite Upgrade Templates craftable with Netherite Scraps and some other ingredients; I would propose 6 scrap, 2 gold ingots and 1 magma cream. Alternatively, bringing down the cost of duplicating only Netherite Upgrade Templates, perhaps to 4 dia and 3 netherrack or 3 dia and 4 netherrack.

The Netherite Upgrade template doesn't make much sense in the context of Minecraft and the design philosophy behind its crafting system. Even outside of the Crafting Table, there's always an implication that the list of ingredients for any item is based in some form of reality or practicality.

Theres the implication that every item is deliberately used for something. With tools for example, we have sticks that are clearly used to make up the handle, and the resources are used for the actual tool part, such as the blade of a sword.

So I ask the question, what *is* the Netherite Upgrade Template? Obviously its the item that allows you to upgrade your gear, but within the *universe* of Minecraft, what is it? What does our character even do with it when upgrading their gear? I can't recall any other instance of this happening within the game. This would be like if you had to craft a Cake by combining Wheat, Eggs and Sugar with some item called "Cake Template".

I think a very simple fix for this would be to just change the name and texture of the item into something that actually exists within the world of Minecraft. Perhaps a powerful Ember that's hot enough to melt Netherite, giving the implication that the Player is using the item to mold Netherite into Armor and Tools. Like how Beskar from Star Wars is melted into Armor. Or maybe some type of Smithing stone, implying youre using it to refine Netherite into Tools and such.

I hope any of what I said made any sense, lol.

if netherite needs to be harder to obtain with more resources, at least do it with something that can be a bit less finite. piglin trading? a boss/mob drop? keeping it in bastions creates a similar problem to elytra, where new players in a survival multiplayer server have to travel much further to get the same resources as the people before

Similar to my concerns that the armor trim system was too expensive i feel that the cloning the upgrade recipe is too expensive. Though my reasoning is a bit different. 1. I am a casual player (i have a standard job and am unable to play minecraft more than a few hours a week) and so the extra hours of grind to get the diamonds to work with netherite is infeasible for me. Even as it stands currently the grind to get ancient debris is barely attainable with my few hours a week i have to play minecraft. Secondly it manifests for me as an accessibility issue. Because of my disability (dexterity and mobility impairments) i have a hard time having a fast reaction or interactions during combat. As a result I have an extremely difficult time during combat situations as the fast reactions necessary are physically difficult for me. This means that I die in most combat situations. I have compensated for this in the past by putting in the grind to get netherite armor or playing in peaceful mode (which loses a lot of the experience of the game tbh) However the increased grind for netherite will make the get geared up strategy even more infeasible. While Smithing Templets are an amazing new implantation to the game there is 1 major flaw in their design which is the accessibility. By giving the wandering trader the chance to spawn with templets, templets can remain hard to obtain but never finite for servers. I am very concerned about Netherite Upgrading requiring a key item that can only be found within Structure generated chests. I feel this will only cause problems within Multiplayer of more dedicated players with more time on their hands getting to Bastions before other players, taking all the Tablets, and closing off access to these upgrades unfairly. Whereas for Singleplayer Worlds, this feature adds nothing. This only slows down the speed at which players gain netherite gear in Singleplayer. Players already are going to want to explore the Nether if they are seeking Netherite Gear, so requiring they find key items within Bastions isn't encouraging new gameplay, it's forcing it instead. This overall does not seem healthy or engaging. It's just slowing down the experience for Singleplayer, and causing risk of people being denied access to Netherite entirely within Multiplayer. The diamond cost is also not an added layer of difficulty, it is just more grind. Anyone can mine seven diamonds. It's not difficult. It's just taking more time to get what we used to be able to get before.

If you really want Netherite to be more expensive, I'd suggest you remove requiring a key item that can be only found in structure generated chests, and focus on making the recipe and process itself. Don't just require one extra RNG item that people are forced to find, add more layers to preparing Debris, Scrap, and Ingots, and up the Ingot cost. This would be healthier for the game I feel.

I have two main thoughts.

The Netherite Upgrade feels a bit out of place in Bastions.

It feels like it'd fit better if it was instead called something like "Ancient scroll" or "Binding instructions," and then have it look like something Piglins would actually write down, like a, well, scroll.

Just having it look like a pouch seems a bit odd.

Also, the crafting recipe feels like it could have more lore to it.  Instead of diamonds or netherrack, why not have things that have been previously shown to be a nether binding agent in it?  Like magma cream or blaze powder.

It'd make more sense because it could be like the "scroll" is instructing you how to bind the netherite to the diamond to make it stronger using the materials instead of just... being a pouch.

Or perhaps the easy way could be taken and just have their durability and strength increased further to just make them that much better than diamond.

And one more thing, the upgrades shouldnt be limited to Bastion loot chests because it'll just become another thing players will hoard in multiplayer and make them impossible to get for others.  They should be a drop from Brutes or possibly something else.  A rare drop, but it'd let other people get them and the recipe for them.

Maybe buff the Netherite tier with something like increase despawn time to make it more valuable, maybe go further and make it so Netherite armor can increase despawn time for surrounding item. It can justify the investment require to upgrade to Netherite.

Template might have durability (2 or 3 point of durability), can be enchant or inject with EXP for increase in durability, cannot be repair, multiplying template require full durability point, using template will decrease the durability. This can lower the amount of grind/exploration needed.

An idea to make duplicating upgrade template more interesting would be to create unique way of crafting like using cauldron with blue fire underneath it, maybe put fire resistance portion (easily acquire treading wtih Piglin) + template + diamonds into the cauldron to duplicate the upgrade template. This increase the difficulty in template duplication process but if template can be use multiple time instate of one time consumable, this could work.

Some say Bastion are annoying to raid, full of lava. Maybe add additional option to obtain upgrade template, maybe it can be found on fortress or upgrade template fragment that can be found in fortress and can be craft into upgrade template.

I was perfectly satisfied with how netherite worked since 1.16 and don't appreciate changes that are just to make the game more difficult or more geared toward the grindcore set. The "Netherite Upgrade" seems indolent and only further complicates things. There is no correlation between the name and the lore of Minecraft. Upgrading to Netherite should be labor-intensive, and it has been working well since 1.16. It doesn't need to be changed.

I think netherite could use several tweaks:

First it needs to be able to be repaired. Either make it so 1 ingot fully repairs it or change the repair material to diamonds

Second i think mending should be removed from villager trades. its supposed to be treasure. Its way to easy to get mending on all your tools so as soon as you get netherite you just have it forever without having to consider reparing it. This way you have to go raid end cities to find mending.

Third bastion remnants should have higher yield of netherite scrap. Raiding them should be a valid alternative to blast mining underground. Either increase the chance in those rooms with 1 chest and 1 double chest or make debris spawn in the walls like gold block do.

I think netherite is already fine the way it is. But if you have to increase its difficulty to get, then make it more renewable somehow. You can still have the templates as rewards for exploring but also add a secondary option. Maybe it could be a boss loot reward. A rare drop from a mob. A trade item. 

I already very much dislike how elytra are pseudo finite items. Please don't ruin netherite. While I bring that subject up, I think elytra need to be given the same treatment in that they need to be renewable somehow. Again like a boss drop or rare drop etc.

My preferred method, if necessary to keep netherite templates, would be to make it similar to beacons. Make a new mob that only spawns at certain locations. Then make some form of rare drop or boss fight available at those locations. That way it makes it so you want to find at least one of those locations and make a base or farm at them. Like nether fortesses for beacons. Nether Fortess->Wither Skeleton->Wither Skull->Wither->Beacon. Do something like that for the templates. Or.. just remove netherite templates

Getting Netherite is extremely grindy already. "Optimum" netherite mining strategies I see online get pro players like 60-70 ancient debris per hour. Being an amateur, including time spent traveling to the now very distant places on my server that have not been mined out yet, I get more like 20-30 ancient debris in an hour.

I'm on a late game server with farms for just about every useful renewable. If I fall into the void, including time traveling to trading halls, xp farms, etc, I'm already looking at like 2-3 hours of play time to refresh my gear. As a casual player, that could be most of my playtime for a week. The current upgrade template recipe would add another 20-50 minutes grinding through deepslate [agony] for 28-42 non-renewable diamonds, depending on my kit at the time. That makes a feature that benefits my play (I die less often and break blocks faster) less available.

I like the idea of needing to find netherite upgrade templates in bastions, but I disagree with them being consumable.  If they MUST be consumable, then the duplication recipe should be a more renewable item, even if the renewability is a bit advanced.  Also, doesn't make sense lore wise for a template to be consumable.  Most templates for building stuff IRL serve as a guide that can be pulled out and reused.

I think the cost of reusing netherite upgrades is too high with seven diamonds. In the progression from wood to stone to iron to diamond at least doubles durability each tier with all tools and armor, armor points go up and the number of blocks that can be instamined under different conditions go up. None of these are true with netherite, and you get max durability increase of 30% for tools and approximately 10% for armor.

This cost might be fine difficulty progression for singleplayer and friendly servers, but on competitive survival servers with PvP making small differences in gear matter more and keepinventory off, and the ability to lose your hard earned netherite armor in literally 2 seconds with a clean doubletap with end crystals, adding more grindiness to netherite just seems like a bad idea, given how many maxed toolsets you'd want, and give people who grinded pre-1.20 an unfair advantage.

What I don't like is that netherite is already such a grind to get, but now also requires 7 diamonds per upgrade. Fair enough, but then... maybe make bastion chests contain more debris?

Another thing... the templates are way too rare. There's barely one per bastion, besides treasure bastions. They should be more common or even guaranteed in bridge variants.

While I understand the need for the netherite upgrade template due to the changes to the smithing table and the introduction of armor trims, the current recipe to duplicate of seven diamonds surrounding one netherrack and the upgrade is way too expensive. A recipe of one to two diamonds plus upgrade surrounded by netherrack makes much more sense. It also matches the texture better. Furthermore, the current chance of finding one (10%) is still way too low. You either need to make bastions easier to find or greatly increase the chance of finding the item(30-50%). One way you could make them easier to find is by making maps usable in the nether and having treasure maps that mark the bastions locations, just like you do for woodland mansions. What you currently have in place is more likely to cause players to switch to creative mode to get netherite gear in single-player worlds.

The bastion vault: A new rare bastion class that is guaranteed to have an upgrade in it along with upgrades being made multi-use, this new structure is maze-like and filled with piglins and piglin brutes, many chests can spawn here with the normal bastion loot, but only one holds the upgrade, and that one is in a portion of the vault called "the central chamber" once you make it here, you're gonna have to face against quite the foe to get the upgrade: a new mini-boss that guards the upgrade chest

The piglin titan: A larger piglin brute (similar size to the warden, albeit much lower stats) who gaurds the upgrade chest in the vault, equipped with gold armor with netherite trim, a netherite axe, and a crossbow to attack players with if they stay out of melee range.

HP: 75 hearts (150 health)
Melee attack: 12.5 hearts (25 damage)

Ranged attack: 6 hearts (12 damage) (Will attack player with spectral arrows to attract other piglins to the fight)

I think we're going in the wrong direction here. The Netherrite Upgrade item is simply here to make a problem that didn't exist in the first place, and it doesn't make too much sense in terms of lore either.

I believe the better option would be to instead provide other upgrade options than Netherrite. Diamond would be the standard all-round armor, Netherrite could be tanky like it normally is but slow you down, and another armor could be more focused on projectile resistance, etc. This way we can nerf Netherrite so that it doesn't feel too overpowered for the time it takes to get it, but also provide other options in case some don't like the change; everyone can now have a more unique playstyle as Netherrite won't be the end-all be-all. This would also give the Smithing Table many more uses.

If bastions are going to become part of progression despite their rarity and difficulty to find, they need to spawn exactly 1 template every time.

Imagine if a stronghold only had a 10% chance to have a portal? Now imagine we didn't have eyes of ender and had to rely on just finding one in the wild. That's what a bastion is. On top of that, we're expected to find at least 4 bastions for armour and 5 for tools, and there's no guarantees there won't be duplicates. At 10% chance it's possible we'll need to find 90 bastions to complete our set, and that's if we don't get duplicates

In my mind, the best solution would be to add a chest to the bastions that are 100% guaranteed to have a "blank netherite template". This template cannot be duplicated, but it can be turned into a template of your choice. Once you craft it into a helmet template for example, THEN you are allowed to duplicate it. This way you still need to explore 9 bastions, but you know that there will be something important every single time you find one and you will have the excitement of exploration without the pain of RNG progression loot that saps the fun out of everything.

I do not think having a template for netherite is a good idea. Locking the crafting recipe for it behind a template that's randomly obtained in a chest would make the game frustrating and doesn't really make sense, since you being able to do all the crafting recipes is the way the game's been. Templates as banner patterns for already-made armor is a lot more in line.

I think it's better to add a new item such as a forge that can't be crafted and can only be mined with a netherite pickaxe, and must be found in the nether (in fortresses, bastions, or other generated structures later down the line.) We can call it a "nether forge" and it could serve as either the only way to smelt ancient debris (with an infinite amount of fuel) or the only way to craft netherite ingots (it has a 4x4 crafting grid and the netherite ingot would require 4 netherite in a line and 4 gold in a line next to each other to craft horizontal or vertical, similar to how bread is crafted.) It breaks quite quickly with a netherite pickaxe and will drop itself, but very slowly with diamond and below and will not drop itself. If you want to mine it and take it home with you, you must do it with a netherite pickaxe, so that way, most of us would have to craft our first netherite gear in the nether. Netherite should also be buffed if it's made harder to craft to justify it, as it's pretty unnecessary and a rather small upgrade to diamond in its current state that nerfing it just for endgame purposes is needless.

It's a great idea, however, the name and the texture really, really bother me. For one, it's just borderline lazy (no offense, you guys are a great team) to call it "netherite upgrade" and put a blue arrow on the texture. In the past, Mojang has always been great at implementing features in a unique way. When the community asked for backpacks, you gave them shulker boxes. When the community asked for lava boats, you gave them striders. This, however, this doesn't have the same unique, "Minecrafty" feel that those other features had. The name and texture break immersion and make it feel like a gameplay feature, rather than a part of the Minecraft universe. My point is, don't call it the "netherite updgrade". Call it, like, I don't know, reinforced diamond, or netherite plating or something. It shouldn't feel like a literal powerup. Right now, this feature feels incredibly cliche, and I hope that this will be changed at some point.

Otherwise, this new snapshot is INSANE. You guys are a great team.

I don't like this at all, if I'm being honest. It feels so much like a mod, from the sprite to the name of the item. Netherite isn't as easy to obtain as one might say, and it isn't as overpowered as this item suggests. To obtain Netherite, you have to brave the Nether in the first place, but then you have to have the resources to find Netherite, whether that be your pickaxe, TNT, or beds. And once you get enough Netherite, all it does is make your tools mine a little faster, your weapons hit a little harder, and gives your armor knockback resistance, with the additional buff of improving durability. But in a world with Mending, this durability buff isn't a big deal. And it's nice to have your gear not burn in fire of lava, but good luck getting to the middle of a lava lake in five minutes or less. Netherite is stronger than diamonds, but only by a little.

So either make Netherite even stronger to justify braving a Bastion, one of the most dangerous structures located in arguably the most dangerous dimension, or make the Upgrade easier to find in the first place. Maybe you can obtain it through Piglin bartering as a very rare drop, which gives the player more of a use for all of their gold. I shouldn't have to feel rushed to get Netherite gear now before 1.20 comes out, because I might as well stick with diamond before I raid a Bastion full of Piglins and Brutes for a small upgrade.

I understand how this makes Netherite a more unique system than traditionally mining and it forces player progression through places outside their comfort zone for a fitting reward...

 

... But for multiplayer servers each person would need to find a maximum of 8 Unique Bastions to get all Netherite Armor/Tools - the hoe. And the 10% rate of finding extra in other places is rare enough that you can't count on finding them in places other than the main treasure chest in each Bastion.

 

To fix this issue and still enforce player discovery, I would have Bastion chests hold a special "item fragment" and when you find 4 of them you can use them to craft a station that can upgrade Diamond -> Netherite the traditional way. That way, it is a permanent reward for exploring x amount of Bastions.

 

TLDR;

Keep Smithing Tables as a way to add trims to armor exclusively, much like the Loom is exclusively for creating banners. But have Bastions hold "item fragments" to upgrade the Smithing Table permanently once you get 4 of the fragments to use them to upgrade Diamond Gear the old way. Call it a Bastion Forge, Netherite Smithing Table, etc.

It would be helpful if there was a rare but renewable way to get these. I understand the need for exploration, but SMP servers with a healthy player base will have scarcity issues. Having a more difficult, but renewable way to obtain the templates would help multiplayer servers to have a more balanced ecosystem. I'd recommend piglin bartering, or maybe an extremely expensive recipe where you put in 2 diamond blocks in place of the template, something of that sort.

Overall, I like the changes to Netherite Upgrading.  I am glad that Netherite armor/tools/weapons have become more expensive in 1.20.

However, I feel that only being able to obtain Smithing Templates as rare loot from Bastion Structures creates a problem on Multiplayer servers.  The older a map gets, the harder it will become for new players to find templates.  This will especially be true on servers which have a smaller world border.

I think it would be perfectly fine to leave Bastion Loot tables as they are, but it would be very helpful to add another expensive method for obtaining Smithing Templates by curing Zombified Piglins.  There are several possibilities, but if it were up to me, it would involve splashing a Zombified Piglin with a status effect, such as Fire Resistance, and then feeding it many golden carrots, similar to the mechanics of feeding a baby horse to accelerate its growth.  Once the Zombified Piglin was cured, it would have a chance of dropping 1 Smithing Template as a "thank you" gift.

Also, I would prefer it if a Smithing Template wasn't consumed when you applied it, but was damaged instead.  You would need to repair it before using it again.  (This probably applies to the Armor Trim Templates as well, and you should still be able to duplicate them, of course.)

To upgrade your diamond tools and armor to Netherite variants, you will now need a Smithing Template called “Netherite Upgrade”, which can only be found in Bastion Remnant chests.

This provdes players with a greater sense of reward, but it also worsens necessity of human moderator intervention on larger, longer-running multiplayer servers, such as through Nether resets. A game as influential and captivating as Minecraft really ought to stand on its own as much as possible, and this is a significant step back on this front.

Another concern is how the default consumption behavior of the item may play out in the social dynamics of different groups, where some players may expect others to preserve these items, while others may be unaware. This can create unnecessary tension and animosity for the game to simply be fun and challenging.

Finally, duplication on a crafting table is a clear outlier in game mechanics. Typically, the ingredients are placed on the left-hand side, with the right-hand side representing a new product. The duplication could be more fittingly and very straightforwardly performed on the smithing table itself. Breaking this paradigm without a compelling reason suggests a lack of care for emergent expectations, a perspective I genuinely want to believe that the team understands.

We’re hoping that this change will unify the gear upgrading system with the introduction of armor trims,

While I understand the intention behind synchronizing these gameplay paths, it's important to distinguish between functional upgrades and cosmetic upgrades. It is not necessary to assume that there should be parity between these two aspects. The system plays reasonably on the cosmetic side, where different players likely want different trims. For tier upgrading, though, the dilemmas seem unwarranted.

as well as make exploring Bastion Remnant structures a more integral part of game progression.

While there may be some metrics by which this marks the game as more complete, I would disagree that structures must contribute irreplaceably to gameplay progression to be worth their inclusion. This philosophy runs the risk of rejecting enjoyable content in favor of a rigid definition of cohesive gameplay experience. It forces Minecraft into a predetermined mold that it may not need to fill, and costs more in terms of player satisfaction than it pays back.

A somewhat seasoned casual player...I do not like the new requirement of a smithing template for creating netherite armor. It is time consuming enough to find ancient debris and create the ingots...the reward should be the armor. Now after spending hours mining for ancient debris, you're rewarded with....more hours of having to search the most dangerous place for the most dangerous structure to possibly get a template. Or not...perhaps you die and lose your debris in the process. Or all the diamond armor you were going to upgrade, plus all of your weapons and tools which were carefully upgraded so you could *unsuccessfully* survive the nether in the first place. Overall, just takes too much time...was borderline already, now just silly. If I spent all this time making the armor, then die and lose it...I'd probably stop playing minecraft altogether. No longer worth the risk...I think you'll see huge swaths of players give up on netherite entirely, going back to just using diamond for everything (myself included).

Minecraft has a wonderful variety of landscapes and resources. Netherite is pretty much the best one. Before the 1.20 update netherite was already a dangerous and stretched goal for those who only want a bit more buff. The netherite upgrade has the potential for many applications. However, it may cause players to skip netherite completely because of the risk of losing diamonds in the flaming wastes of the nether. Creating a full netherite set, without losing diamonds in the process, is nearly impossible. Advanced Minecraft players may have said that it needs to be more challenging, yet what about all the other players who just want to play a fun game? It is disappointing when there was already a set standard for getting netherite, then later the bar gets raised without adding anything useful. How about if the player could also use this upgrade mold to improve their armor? This way, the player would not be held hostage by having to wear diamond and netherite armor in the game.
One problem I see in Minecraft is that players always make the following evolution. Iron Armor -> Diamond Armor -> Netherite Armor. No one takes the time to wear full leather, gold and chain armor, as they don't have good defense, which is understandable for both parties, as players want higher defense, and Mojang can't increase the base defense of armor for no reason 
My idea is that the upgrade molds would improve the weaker armor a few times, until it was at the level of Netherite armor. This way, it would be possible to achieve Mojang's objective, which would be for players to be able to each use their own armor in the game, having their own advantages with them, not needing to make leather or gold boots, as they are needed

It would be great, players using entire sets made of gold, others made of leather, everyone being able to fight each other, with their own individualities

From what I've been told, the idea behind Trails and Tales is about self expression and story telling and for the later, that's hard to do if all the the trail structures the same. Furthermore, the tales being told have to be believable on some level, even after suspending belief. Having this structure in the middle of a lush green area isn't inherently believable since a lot of lore in Minecraft is covered in mystery so we have no baseline level of disbelief.

One could also assume that the idea is that a majority would be mostly underground. I can see where that idea is coming from here. There are roman cities being unearthed as time goes on. But is that what players will do? Or will they just learn where the loot is, grab it, and go.

I also don't think we need these underwater. We already have sunken ships, ocean monuments, and ruins that tell a story. Would be better to redesign or make variants of those. adding a trail, even with conduit power wouldn't be ideal for the reason I mentioned above. People will learn where the loot is, grab it, and go. If there's an easier way to do it above water, then a player would probably do that.

Ok, first of all: contrary to what people are saying, I really appreciate that these structures use terracotta and mud blocks. Could they be prettier? Yes, but I like that they are used instead of stone bricks again. They also help recognize the structure: if you see red terracotta while exploring a forest, you know there's a trail ruin there.

However, these can be a lot better, too, starting with loot. I feel like stone tools make more sense instead of wooden ones, since stone is usually better preserved than wood. Besides that, no one will want to explore a ruin if the only thing they'll get are some low-tier tools, candles, glass panes and pottery shards.

This can be said of all archaeology structures: It's cool that ocean ruins get sniffer eggs, but each structure should have their own unique loot, as well as more useful things overall (nautilus shells in the ocean, anvils in the trail ruins... something actually useful). Tools and crops give ambience, but don't incentivize looting. Not even pottery shards do, sadly.

Right now, the loot doesn't feel all too worth it. I excavated a whole ruin, which got me nearly a full inventory worth of dirt, cobble, gravel and sand, only to dig up a bunch of dyes, glass, and candles. I only got seven things that I would consider worth it out of it. Two leads, two armour trim templates, two emeralds and a single pottery shard isn't enough to make me want to dig out an entire ruin. The junk loot is also far less useful than most junk loot is. Most of the time, you'll be able to get some use out of it, from use as food, to mob drops being somewhat useful. But the junk loot in ruins mostly consist of dyes, candles and glass panes in mismatched colours, not even being able to all be used in a single build without looking inconsistent. Emeralds, pottery shards, and other resources such as gold and iron nuggets should be more common, dyes should be completely removed from the loot table and candles and glass panes should be their base colours if they have to be included still.

¿How can we make Trail ruins more interesting? Making them the new Dungeons!

  • They get challenging: Inside a Trail Dungeon, there are obstacles hiding treasures that the player can find, plus the reward is always greater when it feels like you've earned it.
  • They add Gameplay: To Explore a trail dungeon, the player will need to solve puzzles, fight monsters, dig treasures, or whichever method they find the most fun to get the treasures hiding inside.
  • They feel like Minecraft: There is a lot of unused or outdated content, Dungeons being one of the most popular suggestions among players, The introduction of archeology gives Dungeons the oportunity to catch up with the newest Minecraft content. This can be achieved with content that is already in the game.veterans and new players alike will be able to explore these new and improved structures.

After having dug one up, Its a very mixed structure for me. While the concept of a completely buried structure is nice, I dont think it is in any great way executed upon here.

The structures themselves are a pick and mix of random block pallettes with a (rather nice, to be fair) colorful touch. They are usually indistinguishable towers or ruin piles, with no discernable purpose or interior, and the fact that actually looking at them from above is so hard worsens it. (And yes, I have looked at the structures on their own, and it doesnt get better).

The loot is, and Im gonna say this as nicely as possible, rather pointless. The trims and shards are great, but if you have to get through 12 colors of glass panes, dyes and candles to get a couple, you are not going to appreciate them as much. Its just far too much junk loot. And the "storytelling" aspect isnt helped much, as much more than "they liked colors and farmed a bit" cant be gleamed from it.

Further expanding on the loot topic, there should definetly be either ore blocks or other such loot blocks in the structure so that digging up every piece is more encouraged.

Lastly, the structures need some empty space. Yes, digging up stuff is all nice and well, but it would be infinitely more satisfying to sometimes come upon a somewhat preserved room or hall.

To summarize: They need a consistent visual theme, an extreme reduction of "junk loot", possibly existing pots or ore blocks, empty spaces and just more recognizable buildings.

It is a unique concept which already makes it intriguing. However, the use of terracotta could better fit in the badlands as long as the colours differ from terrain generation. For other biomes, something a little less contrasting might be more pleasant to the eye (perhaps cobblestone in plains, deepslate in Taiga etc.). Glazed terracotta is a strange block and rarely works well in builds. My suggestion would be to either replace it in the structure by a different one or retexture it if possible. If the time and resources are available, a more polished deepslate crypt could be a nice addition to the already fantastic trail ruin. It would make great use of the chiseled bookshelf block. By being more polished, it could also seem like a secret bunker of the civilization that might have once resided in the trail ruins.

I think Trail Ruins is a great idea! Buildings made of terracotta and mud bricks are in a colorful style that has never existed before, and the fact that dyed glass and candles can be excavated suggests that there must have been a civilization with excellent dyeing technology at that time. Also, some of the buildings are reminiscent of blacksmiths and Pillager outspots, and it's fun to imagine tales of fallen civilizations. Part of the structure has collapsed due to the passage of many years, but I think it is a good decision that the collapse is limited to the extent that it is possible to restore the original shape. In fact, I still enjoy restoring these buildings and recreating what they used to be!
But I think there are some things that could be improved. When the ruins of the journey are generated, in the java edition all but the top of the tower are buried in the ground, whereas in the bedrock edition most of them are exposed. I hope both editions will eventually bring the two generational styles together, as the fun of unearthing hidden things and exploring weathered architecture is both irresistible.
Also, I think it's an interesting idea to combine smaller units to create a single house, but I think that there aren't enough cyan terracotta and brick-style units in the building blocks.

I like the concept of the structure's loot table, providing resources for players to reconstruct and decorate the ruins, however think it could use a few minor tweaks to this end.

For a start, including specifically the hanging signs as opposed to ordinary signs seems only to be due to the item sharing an introductory update with the structure, while an ordinary sign is more fit to purpose for decoration as the player can augment it with a chain by their decision; the reverse is not possible. Signs could also utilize a wood type matching the surrounding biome, making sense historically but also automatically matching to the player's available materials for consistent decoration.

While stained glass makes sense historically, the structure's underground placement presents the player with very few opportunities to apply it. I could suggest removing the stained glass from the loot table and instead including it in the existing structure, giving a clearer suggestion these buildings once existed above ground and ultimately not filling the table with items the player is unlikely to use.

The clay blocks in the table stand out unusually, being the only full block. I could suggest replacing it with clay's material form, or including the occasional clay block in the original structure.

Finally, leather (for item frames), empty maps (to incentivize cartography) and banner patterns (to incentivize use of banners in decoration) could make for useful additions to the loot table.

Additionally to my previously uploaded thoughts; ran out of message space:

The dyes provided by the structure's loot table do not particularly correspond to those making up the structure, supplying the player with redundant colors and leaving them without access to those necessary for reconstruction.

To elaborate: the orange and light blue colors of terracotta appear in small quantities within the structure, and can be easily obtained using the other dyes provided by the structure in combination with those easily accessed in a variety of biomes. While the inclusion of these colors isn't particularly problematic, they are less useful in crafting other colors, and providing them limits an opportunity to lean into the color mixing crafting system.

On the other hand, cyan dye is not supported by the loot table, is difficult to get a hold of without access to cactus, and its respective clay color is applied in high quantities in this structure. To ensure a player will be capable of completing a structure without necessitating access to a desert, I recommend providing green or cyan dye in the loot table, or introducing another method to access the dye not dependent on a particular biome. Alternatively, the structure's palette could be biome-dependent, using materials available in the surroundings.

Adding more small air pockets within the walls of the rooms could be really good for pushing the idea of a lived-in space. Right now, they are a bit claustrophobic, and don't feel like a real livable space yet. More open room, less than but similar to the ocean ruins, or the shipwrecks, just enough to speed up uncovering ruins / looking for suspicious blocks a little, and to push that space. Ancient cities are a great example of a build of a protected/strong underground space, and we could find weaker or even older examples like this through the ruins.

Rarer or more complex drops would also incentivize excavation, like items covered in clay that have to be cleaned in a cauldron, rare pots that hold items/exclusive shards, or items trapped within hardened sandstone (chisel?). These blocks could generate slightly around the structure so players mining/digging would be made aware of it naturally, and can uncover it slowly, rather than it already poking out. Maybe items could be higher up if they were lighter or harder to bury, things like bones (dog interactions) or small bundles. Players who fully excavate it would get more rewarded and engage further with the ruins. A new boss could even be uncovered through this, akin to getting 3 wither skeleton skulls.

I think adding many variations (biome/high/low/even dimension) will also keep the engagement enjoyable and continue to be a worthwhile investment for players! So far it looks really promising but it needs to be pushed further!

Glazed Terracotta Sculptures will generate in a structure section beneath Trail Ruins in 2 by 4, 4 by 4 or 3 by 3 layout. The Armour Pieces which forms the Sculpture are based of the texture and colour palette of Glazed Terracotta Blocks but the Terracotta Armour Pieces cannot be crafted and but can be dropped on a Dripstone stalagmite placed below the block the sculpture is on and then break that block and the sculpture breaks and becomes an item that can be placed like an Armour Stand and the player can change the pose of the sculpture with a redstone powering the block the sculpture is placed on.

Personally I love the idea of trail ruins, however i feel the overall execution of the structure is lacking. For instance, I saw a video of a person who excavated and mined out all the sand and gravel from the structure, and it looked absolutely amazing! But this was only AFTER excavation, meaning the good looks of said structure are buried by way to much sand and gravel, destroying any aesthetic appeal to the structure. Not to mention the fact that there isnt too many valuable things other than trims that you get from brushing sand and gravel.

 

So how do we fix this? First of all lets tackle the aesthetic problem. Currently, the whole thing is buried, and there is not even a clue to as what this thing was in it's prime. So what about we change the trail ruin to look more like an abandoned mineshaft, its still buried, and you have to dig down through the central "pile" but once inside, it is hollow. Inside it looks like a mineshaft with some of the hallways having collapsed and filled by brush-able sand and gravel. this would fix the structure aesthetically.

 

And then add better loot.

When riding the camel, if your head clips into a block (for instance when you ride through a 3 block high gap) the camel's speed slows down drastically. This really becomes an issue when you clip your head inside of a solid block and start suffocating, as it becomes a lot harder to get out.

I think a good way to prevent camels from becoming like horses (tamed for the advancement and then left in a barn for eternity) is to allow players to put villagers on camels. This would solve the lack of intuitive transport methods on land, as minecarts are too inflexible and expensive, while boats can’t go up even a pixel and are just too slow. The size of the camel would prevent it from getting into small spaces, so these other methods would still have to be used for the final bit of manoeuvring into small areas and won’t be completely replaced. You’d probably shift click to remove the villager from the camel, so you didn’t have to kill it.

This ability to transport villagers would encourage players to find and use camels when they want to build an iron/raid farm or a trading hall, and also creates unique storytelling opportunities, as people can add camel riding merchants to their cities, or take their villager friends on adventures with them to trade for food or arrows while out and about.

Despite the fact that the camel is a pretty cute mob, besides it is a good alternative horse, they need a couple more improvements for full implementation: 
1) At the moment, you can just throw a saddle on it and immediately ride, unlike horses or llamas. It seems to me that the player must first tame him by feeding him cactus/sugar cane/hay blocks. Maybe because of his size, he will require more food. 
2) It is very strange that mobs such as Endermen, Illagers and Piglins are not able to throw you off the saddle. I think we can let them do it. Or they can kill the camel first and then attack the player. 
3) A camel simply MUST be able to carry a load. It seems to me that in order to be as balanced as possible, you can allow both players to place one Bundle on it, or one player - two Bundles. On the one hand, it seems like you can carry cargo, but on the other hand, the same horse will have a full-fledged chest. 
4) I'm missing some kind of unique interaction between the player and the camel. I think it would be fun to let the players hang their banners on them.

While a nice aesthetic addition to the desert environment, I don't feel like the camel has much of a way to carve out its own niche in Minecraft's current sandbox.

The fact it is a two-seater is worthless in singleplayer, the security it offers from melee mobs is better offered by a horse's sheer speed, while the long jump "dash" both doesn't feel fitting for the otherwise slow and steady camel to have and can still be mostly matched by some of the more agile horses.

Giving it storage capacity would turn it into little more than a desert llama or donkey, giving it armor to make it a proper warmount would make it step further into the horse's territory and giving it some sort of useful, unique drop is out of the question since you wouldn't want to teach people, that breeding camels for slaughter is a good idea. Getting more fantastical with additional features also seems tough to make work, since the camel is so squarely based on real life, so ideas of that sort would just feel out of place.

I have no idea what could be done to make them truly stand out in terms of mechanics.

I love the new Camels, but there is a few changes and features that I would like to see happen that relates to Camels and 1.20...

1. The animation for Camels is currently inaccurate to its real life counterpart. They're one of the few animals to have a pacing as its walking type. Pacing is where both legs on the same side move at the same time. They do not alternate like most animals.

2. Camels do eat Cactus in real life, but they also eat Prickly Pears which is a type of fruit found in Cacti. From memory, Prickly Pears was originally a planned feature included to the Badlands in the Minecraft Live 2019 Biome Vote. It lost to the Mountains alongside Mangrove Swamps. The latter eventually got added to 1.19's infamous "The Wild Update". I think it is very fitting to include either just the Prickly Pears and its cactus, or all the features that was shown for the Badlands from that Biome Vote. (also add whatever was in the Biome Votes for Desert and Savannah, they seem to fit the warmth of whatever this update is supposed to be)

  • First thing being - how could we dismount mobs. For sure we don't want to kill camel like boats. I thought maybe entities can dismount, when player takes off a saddle. Another idea may be that they would do that after camel lays down after the journey.

I do not like that they named the mob "Camel". Camel is used to name the singular specific species the Bactrian camel, or the genus where both camels and dromedaries are in. To put it simply; I think that the mob Camel should be named Dromedary. The mob we see represents a Dromedary in every way exept the name.

Because it is true that this new animal is in the genus Camelus, but I really think that we should name it after what species it is, and not what genus it belongs to. Because i do not think that players are going to conscious think of the camelid genus, (wich is a part of the family Camelidae), when they see this bright long-legged ungulate with a singel hump. I would think that players would unconsciously expect to see the name of the species of the mobs they see. 

I feel that calling it by its genus name camel is like naming the mob panda as bear, or the mob pig as swine, or name us humans as hominidae; great apes.

Or almost like calling the mob panda as Sloth bear, or the mob pig as boar, or name us humans as chimpanzee. They are both in each example are closely related, but still different.

It is still early in the development. The sooner they could change the name to the species instead, the better. Especially before it reaches all players when 1.20 itself comes out.

• Sprint: For a limited period, you can make the camel run faster and easily avoid the enemies chasing you. So it could be an excellent replacement for a horse.
  • Dash: Similar to sprint, the dash ability allows camels to move quickly from one location to another. Instead of an increase in speed, this ability is similar to a quick long jump, which can be useful in crossing dangerous ravines and water bodies.
  • Speed: In complex terrains, camels are much slower than horses. But in flat areas, they can gain speed over time, which should allow them to easily compete with horses. Racing the camel against a horse to see who’s faster will be our priority when Minecraft 1.20 betas and preview
  •  

 

  • Healing: Just like players, camels slowly heal themselves over time. This ability isn’t affected by their hunger, energy, or movement.

• The time it takes for a sniffer to dig up seeds feels reasonable, yes. Perhaps if anything it could vary depending on the "rarity" of the seed? Like rarer plant seeds take longer.
  • Yes, it does feel like the sniffer is searching for seeds.
  • The growth mechanics do feel intuitive.
  • I feel like Sniffers move just a little bit too slowly, a slight speed increase would be great.

As far as other feedback:

  • Sniffers should either be made a little bit taller, or have some size variation. They are essentially dinosaurs after all.
  • Torchflowers should give off light, maybe even the same level as torches, given the name.
  • I know this is just the first snapshot, but I hope we get at least a handful(like 5-6) plants that the Sniffer can dig up seeds for, if not more. It would be cool if some were even biome-exclusive seeds(perhaps even some exclusive to the Nether?). Suggestions:
    • A overworld-equivalent of weeping vines that can be climbed
    • Some kind of prehistoric-looking fern plant or fern, like Cycads, Selaginella lepidophylla or Horsetail restio. Plants from the Jurassic period in particular would be good inspiration sources.
    • Some kind of flowering vine would be really cool
    • Something like the formerly extinct Judean Date Palm would be cool
  • This may already be planned for when the Sniffer eggs are introduced, but I think that when Sniffers are bred they should lay an egg instead of a Snifflet directly.

Sniffer looks great and is a fantastic addition to the Minecraft mob roster! Even more exciting though is the potential for the many unique ancient plants that can be found using the sniffer. I am of firm belief that functionality outside of visual appeal is always good for any new Minecraft addition, as it allows new items or features to connect with more players who have differing interests. Here are some of my ideas for the new ancient plants: 

Torchflower: 

  • The torchflower should emit some level of light passively (Light level 7 or 14). I think it would be a fun and unique quality to this strange plant! I could also see it emitting a certain light level upon the player walking through the hitbox of the torchflower. 

Mob Lure: 

  • This ancient plant/flower could be reminiscent of carnivorous plants or plants that smell of rotting flesh like the rafflesia! This could then be used as a lure for certain hostile mobs that would be drawn to such alluring smells, like zombies or spiders.  

Color Shifting Flower: 

  • This flower could change appearance/shift in color like how certain flowers (Hydrangeas) change color depending on the PH level of the soil they are planted in. 
  • The seeds when planted in certain blocks (dirt, mud, etc) would change the outcome of how the flower looks after it is grown. 
  • Transplanted flowers could shift color in a similar way to oxidizing copper blocks, once they are moved to a certain block. 
  • It could also drop different dyes depending on its current color.

I always love when mobs have unique interactions with blocks or items in game. Given that these new ancient plants could have varieties of flowers outside of just the torchflower, I think it would cool if a modern mob like the bee had unique interactions / functionality with ancient flowers! Bees could, if only allowed to pollinate ancient plants/flowers, produce unique variations of honey (kind of like how they do in real life!). Given that ancient plants/flowers could have unique compounds not found in the modern times, unique variations of honey with certain effects could be made. For example, bees that pollinate exclusively the torchflower, could create more orange variation of honey that when consumed could give a short burst potion effect like night vision. I think this would give even more functionality to the ancient plants and also give a unique mob interaction outside of the sniffer itself.

The theory that Creepers are plants could allow for these two creatures to have an interesting connection.

I propose a bran new Feature for the Sniffer. Said feature will be heavily linked to the Snowfall Weather, in Cold Biome:

  • The mechanism :

Whenever the Sniffer is in a Cold Biome that allows Snowfall to appear when the weather is rainy, it will change their skin after some time for this one! (For reference, check the link picture.)

When the Sniffer in this "covered in snow" state is within a warmer biome (or under rain), the snow melts, and the skin revert to the original one.

The player can manually do that, by right-clicking the Sniffer with a shovel, which drops a few snowballs depending on the size of the mob. (example: 1-3 snowballs for the adults, and 1 for the children.)

  • The reasons:

This would give the Sniffer more of a place within a world that isn't native to them. Not only are they the largest passive mob in Minecraft, but they are rather slow in movement, meaning they would have snow collect on themselves (similar to real life bisons). It would truly make the world interact with them more.

The Sniffer is a fantastic mob! It has so much more potential to improve for some minor changes until the release of update 1.20.

• For one, I would find most suitable for Sniffers to lay eggs, rather than simply spawning a baby Snifflet after breeding. If the player is required to revive the Sniffer species by finding ancient eggs, then it would be most reasonable for the Sniffer to be an egg-laying mob, like the Turtle. So, in short, baby Snifflets should hatch from eggs laid after breeding.
• Secondly, the Sniffer should have higher HP. An HP of 60 (30 hearts) seems like a reasonable amount.
• And lastly, Sniffers and Parrots should have some sort of symbiotic relationship, as Bees would've had with the Moobloom. Perhaps, even, the Sniffer could allow Parrots to perch on their backs.

Hi There!!

The Sniffer looks and feels amazing especially with the latest updated snapshot that recently came out however I do need to express some concern.

The mechanic to find new and interesting plants in incredible and seeing the new pitcher plant has me so excited for the future of what has become my favourite feature. This is a fantastic way to add more plants to the game without over cluttering biomes however 2 (I know a third plant has apparently been leaked) is nowhere near enough. Getting the sniffer is a fair amount of effort from the player, not only do you have to go out searching for the location to find the sniffer egg but we still might not even have a chance to get one if we happen to be unlucky in the dig site we come across. Now this is all fine, my friends and I are personally looking forward to the adventure of finding a sniffer but all of that effort needs to be rewarded with a lot more than 2 (3) plants.

I think on release of the sniffer we need at least 4-6 plants at minimum followed by adding a few more plants to this feature in the future. I like the new ancient plants and how they're acquired - they remind me a lot of wither roses, insofar as they can't be renewed with bone meal and require some interaction with a mob to reproduce. However, wither roses can apply a status effect to mobs and the player; I think the Torchflower and Pitcher Plant should be given the same utility. Specifically, they should apply other damage over time effects: naturally, the Torchflower sets entities on fire, and perhaps the Pitcher Plant poisons them.

I also want to echo other commenters with regards to biome-specific ancient seeds. Requiring the Sniffer to dig within different biomes to find all the ancient seeds is similar to biome temperature deciding a Frog's color. It's a relatively small feature that would go a long way in further developing this new mob.

Additionally, if a third ancient plant is added before 1.20 releases, perhaps it's the Sniffers' food of choice? A creature that large could not sustain itself with small flower seeds, and adding ancient food still allows for the same behavior that Torchflower Seeds currently enable (breeding and luring Sniffers). It's also not strictly necessary that the player be able to eat this new food, given that the biology of these ancient plants is strange and alien to the present world of Minecraft.

Finally, I like what others have said about the Sniffer being able to dig up modern plants and/or seeds. I think a feature like that could be a great way to add renewable Spore Blossoms.

Spore Blossom Seeds from Sniffers

The Sniffer egg hatches quicker on moss blocks and the flower seeds it does dig up are for already extinct plants. Spore blossoms are found in mossy caves and also cannot be bonemealed at the moment. From a storytelling standpoint, it could be argued that spore blossoms are a flower species on the decline and their method of replicating has been forgotten thus leading to an eventual extinction in the future. Bringing back an extinct species like the sniffer could be a cool way to save the dying plant species.

Although the spore blossom is found on the ceilings of lush caves, it's not too crazy to think their seeds could be on the moss at the bottom of the caves. Players may already gather moss on their own to hatch the egg or have some as ground cover in their gardens, so it could be a fun reward for the player to reunite their sniffer with some moss in addition to them hatching quicker.

I would love to have sniffer only to hatch on the moss block. It would engage people to look for it and also it would prevent normal sniffer egg to hatch so it could be used as decoration - same mechanic as turtle eggs on sand!

The sniffer needs more ancient plants to dig up: maybe an Apple Sapling.

This would grow into a tree with an oak trunk and a crown of oak leaves mixed with fruiting leaves (a new block). The fruiting leaves would slowly flush with apples, which could be right clicked to remove, or left on the tree for decoration. Fruiting leaves would just drop apples when broken or de-spawned, so the only way to obtain more saplings would be from the sniffer.

The Sniffer needs more plants to sniff up: how about Coral Larvae. 

This would be a stony, fossilized item which when right-clicked in water would release a bunch of particles which would sink to the ocean floor or river bed. Over time, a single coral formation would grow there, block by block.

This would give us renewable coral and make conduits more useful for tending our underwater, renewable coral farms!

The sniffer needs more plants to dig up: How about a Sun-Vine.

This would be a sapling which could be planted alongside 8 other saplings to produce truly giant versions of those trees: for instance 1 Sun-Vine sapling and 8 oak saplings would grow a huge oak tree with a 3 by 3 trunk. The same could be done with dark oak or jungle, etc. Some of the logs in the trunk would be replaced with a new log type, Sun wood, which would spiral up the trunk, dotted with single blocks of leaves. Sun wood could be an opportunity for a new wood family, or it could just break down into string, since it is a fibrous vine and its real effect is to produce epic, giant trees.

Mojang, if you see this, sniffers should find more plants.

White Pumpkin
White pumpkins could be found in the Pale Garden.

Rice
Rice could be grown like wheat. You could eat it in a bowl or turn it into sushi using raw fish and cooked kelp. A rice bowl restores a lot of hunger. Sushi restores one hunger point and restores one full heart. You could have 8 sushi in a stack.

Pansy
The pansy would be a yellow and purple flower. It could be brewed to make a Potion of Aptitude which increases the amount of XP you earn.

Lemons
You could grow lemon trees and harvest lemons. Lemons could be used to make lemonade. You would need to drink the lemonade twice. Drinking it once would clear your effects and it would infuse any effects you had into the lemonade. It would also save the remaining time. Drinking it again would give you the effects.

Corn
Corn would grow like sugar cane, but on dirt instead of sand. This would let you make automated corn farms. You could make corn bread which is crafted identical to bread, but with three corn instead of three wheat. It would restore equal or more hunger points. You could also make popcorn by cooking corn on a campfire or in a furnace.

Garlic
Garlic could be used to make garlic bread which would keep phantoms away from you.

Venus Flytrap
You could put it into a pot and keep it tiny, or you could plant it in the dirt and use bonemeal to make it grow big quickly. It will eat creepers. After 5-12 days, it will spit out the gunpowder.
